Good question and I'm not entirely sure how to represent the answer - the charms use Juju, Juju provides machines for the charms to run on - for most OpenStack deployments that would mean MAAS as the provider is actual hardware.  That is all very much implicit rather than explicit - i.e. there is not really a deployment approach for the charms which involves manually provisioning some machines and then deploying the charms on them.
I think claiming the capability is appropriate here (or at least the closest approximation to a more complex landscape)

sushy_tools/emulator/main.py.message: I know it's not related to this change, but this should go up before the imports from sushy_tools as this is a third imported library

This is exactly one of the reasons I hate this whole patch chain: you're calling into System to do the actual work. There is no Manager resource in reality, you're forcing the operator to make it up for you. And I'm firmly -1 on that.

Right, we have discussed that in other patches.

To reiterate: this is exactly how Redfish puts things together. Managers "own" the drives and hand them over to Systems they manage to boot from. I agree that may seem counterintuitive, but that's how it is. In this patch chain I am trying to follow this Redfish model because I think that otherwise we won't be able to emulate other resources.

Perhaps this is the point of contention - you are arguing that we should put everything into the systems driver (specifically, into libvirt) because this is what we actually use for systems emulation. I think I am not convinced and these are my counterarguments.

You pointed out that Systems and Managers are not orthogonal therefore we should not have dedicated drivers to emulate them. I think they are actually orthogonal and not tightly coupled e.g. you can have X Systems and Y Managers where Y > 0.

I think that other resources emerge that we need to emulate, in the light of that systems driver does not seem to be a good fit... Consider the indicator resource - if we follow the systems-centric approach, will we add methods like `get_chassis_indicator(ident)` to libvirt driver? You've proposed to use the same ident for all resources being accessed through the system (chassis, manager). But that will become incredibly messy if we'd want to emulate more complex relationships between resources. With Redfish many-to-many is possible:

* one Manager can serve multiple Systems and Chassis
* multiple Managers can serve the same System or Chassis
* Chassis can enclose Manager(s), System(s), Drives etc.
* one Chassis can enclose the other Chassis recursively

It seems that modeling such a many-to-many relationships with non-unique  UUIDs feels like a sure path to future suffering. On top of that, I am not sure it is a good idea to produce JSONs with duplicate UUIDs for different objects - this is something that should never happen from probabilistic standpoint.

There is nothing resembling Manager resource realistically atm. If that argument holds, what about the indicators resource? It seems similarly virtual or static, but it is actually useful for testing ironic indicators. You mentioned elsewhere that we should use static simulator for such unrealistic resources. But with indicators we need to have it writable, that can't be done with static emulator.

I do not see it as a problem having pieces of information configured statically to the emulator. We sort of already do that with templates. BTW,  we do not actually use the static emulator, AFAIK. May be conceptually merging static with dynamic is a way to go?

This resource separation design I am trying to propose is open-ended -- should we get something to base resource emulation upon, we could just add another driver for that. This works other way round - should we miss some realistic backend for the resource, the resource framework allows replacing the missing resource with a static mock driver.

Consider my RaspberryPi-based Redfish controller we've presented at devconf as a use-case. There we plugged systems driver with the one actuating relays (by rude hardcode back then) and would replace indicators resource driver with the one lighting the real physical LEDs on the board.

Pardon my long comment!

> To reiterate: this is exactly how Redfish puts things together.

Redfish is an API, not an internal architecture design. It's created to cover all kinds of weird cases, which even real hardware doesn't have too often. We have two cases: libvirt and openstack, and we're very unlikely to ever have more.

>  I think they are actually orthogonal and not tightly coupled e.g. you can have X Systems and Y Managers where Y > 0.

Redfish can, we cannot. It's not going to happen with the backends we have, and virtual media is not going to work this way. It requires 1-1 mapping, and that's what you have.

> You've proposed to use the same ident for all resources being accessed through the system

Right, because they *are* systems from backend perspective. Of course you can generate Manager UUID by XOR-ing System UUID with a constant, I don't mind. But having a user invent fake resources because of your architectural decisions simply means the decisions are not quite right. This is the key point of my objections, I'm more or less fine with somewhat overcomplicated internal structure.

> On top of that, I am not sure it is a good idea to produce JSONs with duplicate UUIDs for different objects

No sane consumers should care about that as long as resource types are different (but again, use XOR if it worries you :)

> It seems similarly virtual or static, but it is actually useful for testing ironic indicators.

You can store an indicator status on a system, if you want to. Anyway, system is the only backend you really have where you can store any state.

Also I'd question the "useful" bit. How is it useful if it does not have a physical representation? What are you testing? It looks like you'll test that code you wrote for ironic works with code you wrote for sushy-tools. I trust you to write code that is consistent with itself :)

> With Redfish many-to-many is possible.
> Consider my RaspberryPi-based Redfish controller

Let's not keep talking about things that have no application to sushy-tools.

This is main the issue, and it is interesting, I have a patch before, which uses the ResourceProcessingQueue to prevent such issue:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/275614/

The issue I tested is concurrently creating and deleting the router.

Of course this is the main issue and that's why I'm proposing this patch. We can't allow two threads to send RPC messages to update the same routers because we can have the situation when an old message overwrites a newer value.

The batch notifier is used by the L3 agent, the Ironic notifier, the Nova notifier, the Nova segment notifier and the placement report plugin. All of them use synchronized callbacks, that's the goal of the BatchNotifier. If we are sending the RPC calls in a non-blocking way, using parallel threads, what's the purpose of the BatchNotifier?
Seems this patch partially reverts [1], it is still 'cast' for that method.

specs/newton/hot-parser.rst.message:
I'm going to bikeshed on the name here a bit, because I think what we actually want is a library to manipulate Heat templates in a programmatic way that is entire independent of the actual template format, plus a way to both parse existing templates (of any format) such that we can start manipulating them that way and a way to output the results.

Also, this is the way I already implemented it, so it's easier too :)

So the way I see it actually parsing HOT is at most 20% of the job of this library, and not even the most interesting 20%, and the name should reflect that.

Couple others as we talked at the summit, 
heat-template-library
heat-template-sdk
make it simple, python-heat-template

FWIW actual JSON and XML 'parsers' are called things like libjson, libxml, DOM and SAX. (TIL that SAX stands for Simple API for XML. I LOLed.)

+1 for any of the suggestions above.
LOL! So one more option to above list as we finalize the name (there seems no naming convention), heat-template-pylib

I also see it as the DOM being the interesting part and there being a number of (de)serializers that go to and from formats, so a few suggestions:

python-heat-templates
python-heat-template-utils
python-heat-template-model

I tried to name in similar line with JSON parser, XML parser, as it helps to parse the given Text document in the python object and helps vice-versa. I'm thinking of what other name to? Kindly recommend me.
After summit, I think we're more in line with this being a model for the templates and one or more supported formats for serialization. We should change this short description to reflect that.
Sure, that sounds good.

I'm not sure about this one. If the cloud provider is providing a template design tool then I'd expect that the cloud prrovider is also running a Heat endpoint that you can validate against (otherwise what are you designing for???).

I don't see client-side validation as the primary use case here, and beyond basic syntax I don't even see it as *a* use case because much of the validation we do doesn't make sense outside the context of a particular Heat service.

This is a great point, which dovetails with what we were saying in the validation session about Heat using the word 'validate' to mean too many different things.

So a library that checks that the template is 'well-formed' (to borrow a term from XML) would be super useful. If we can add in checking of stuff like some function arguments (e.g. get_resource refers to a real resource, get_param refers to a real parameter) that would also be useful. Checking resource schemas and the like would be out of scope because those are cloud-specific.

It helps while authoring the hot template, author goes in many iteration to bring up the *proper* template, which is independent of the parameters. if we provide a tool for generating/validating proper template, it would make their life easier.

Could easily also add:

* Senlin and Murano - both of these services build Heat templates dynamically
* Potentially Trove, Sahara and Magnum - these services use static Heat templates, but might be interested in something more dynamic if a library were available.
* Anyone who has ever asked for more sophisticated template templating features in Heat and been told (usually by me) to go build their own template preprocessor. If this were easier maybe they wouldn't ask so much. (Maybe this falls under "Automation" already.)
Yes on Tacker's use of HOT and Heat (they are using heat-translator as well for translation of NFV profile to HOT).

Let us assume that, we provide class ResourceType to create an resources in HOT template, then it can be created as below:

srv_r = ResourceType("OS::Nova::Server")

srv_r.properties should have all those required properties which could be created, if we have the output of 'heat resource-type-template'. One of the way i was thinking is given below.

-2 on this part.

It's a mistake to think that there is a single set of Heat schemas per Heat release. There is only what *your* cloud supports *right now*. That may be any version of Heat (including random versions of master - e.g. Rackspace runs like this IIUC), and may even be a heterogeneous mix of resource types from different versions (past, present and future), it may only include a subset of the built-in resources, and it may additionally include third-party resources.

It's meaningless to talk about the schema of a particular resource type independently of a specific cloud.

In passphrase_catalog line 33 of [0] we set the prompt value to False if it's not specified in the passphrase catalog.

At the CLI if --interactive is used, or in the passphrase catalog if prompt: True is used then we get into interactive mode and let the user create their own secret.  If the type specified in the passphrase catalog is either uuid or base64 we validate that they are uuid or base64 like strings.

If they are not, they are prompted to try again.  At the new prompt they will have the option to leave blank and exit interactive mode to use automatic generation instead.  Any time a validation checks is failed the user gets a message that the passphrase entered is not a uuid like or base64 like string depending on the type specified in passphrase catalog.

The only 3 categories of secrets we're supporting in passphrase catalogs are UUID and random passphrases that are either normal strings or base64 encoded.  All 3 cases also support user generated secrets, verification will be done to make sure they're the right "type" of secret, but no complexity requirements are enforced. Can you provide more details on the exact use case you are attempting to address? Is it simple bulk port creation, or is it highly concurrent port creation from multiple clients on the same network? The approach for dealing with these scenarios is quite different in my opinion.

I find this approach to be inappropriate for simple bulk port creation, but perhaps effective for handling highly concurrent port creation initiated by multiple clients.

1 Please see reference [1] for more details:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1777968
2 My scenario is to create 1000 virtual machines from the horizon at one time or using cmd "neutron port-create" in script send 1000 calls, which will concurrently request 1000 times create_port methods.

Keep in mind that a lot of these problems exist because ML2  interacts with IPAM in a very un-optimized way on bulk port creation. In its current state, introducing locking in IPAM will only hurt the performance of bulk port creation as it invokes IPAM once for every port it creates.

I would say that the first step is to refactor ML2 such that bulk port creation interacts with IPAM in a bulk manner. If we find that to be insufficient, then we should pursue this approach.
Thanks,I am testing to evaluate if there is any impact on the bulk port creation.
This is true, the current approach in neutron is an optimistic approach that optimizes for the best case.

Does this mean operators can opt in/out if they choose? I am supportive of this being optional, with ip_allocate_with_tooz defaulting to False to allow operators to opt in if they so choose. Tooz shouldn't be forced on operators, so I like that this is configurable.

I agree with Ryan here. You can avoid code duplication by extracting some common pieces to some BaseDriver class and reuse it in 2 different drivers. That is not a problem. And this ipam_driver config option is knob which You actually need to make it configurable to use or not use new driver :)

Please see above.

I disagree. This is the perfect situation for implementing another IPAM driver. I make the distinction between duplication of code and duplication of logic. I don't envision us re-writing the exact same code or performing large copy/paste dumps when writing a new driver. If we find that happening, we should refactor the IPAM interface, which coincidentally has been discussed before. In this case, we're talking about duplication of logic. That is natural when you think about driver implementations of any kind. Different drivers may logically do many of the same things, but how they do it is different. That's what we're talking about here.

In this case, I think it makes sense to pursue another IPAM driver. It allows us a lot of flexibility in terms of re-thinking the implementation without disturbing the current install base. Once it's ready, users can opt in and we can consider deprecating the old default driver and providing a migration path to a new and shinier driver (if something other than a config change is even needed).

The IPAM driver interface exists for the very purpose of supporting different IPAM backends, in my mind this is exactly the scenario where it shows its utility.

Thanks,
In my opinion, the current ipam driver, only the allocation of ip address may cause conflicts, which is related to the two interfaces "create_port" and "create_port_bulk". If we  implement a new ipam driver, it will repeat a lot of the same code, so I suggest to introduce the distribution Lock to the current ipam driver instead of writing a new one.

This is a good idea. If we want to pursue this implementing it as a new IPAM driver is the cleanest approach. That allows operators to opt in and we can compare its performance against the current default IPAM driver.

IPAM already have "drivers" concept: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/688bbdd5cd10a13b010902525617fd43d8a415b6/doc/source/admin/config-ipam.rst

nit: these three sentences could be worded more clearly, eg, 

  Ironic can use either BIOS or UEFI mode when booting servers,
  both for the provisioning (IPA) environment and for the tenant instance.
  However, UEFI secure boot mode is only supported for the tenant instance.

  This work proposes to add UEFI secure boot mode support for the provisioning
  (IPA) environment as well.
Done

Done

(I know the answer, but for the sake of clarity, please indicate it here in terms of ironic's API)
Done

Using a CONF option here will require this to be enabled across the
entire Ironic cluster -- at least for that driver.

Is that the intent?

Also, I'd recommend a slight change to the option name - it's easy to read "in_secure_boot" as "insecure_boot", which means the opposite :)

perhaps "require_secure_deploy_if_secure_boot" or "secure_boot_and_deploy"

Or perhaps just "secure_deploy_mode" is more clear?

Yes. Other option is to add property into deploy image. But then it would put dependency on glance and solution will not work in standalone Ironic.

Will change the config variable name to "secure_deploy_mode".

Hmm... I don't like this.

If the option is set to True but the request does *not* specify this capability,
what is the behavior going to be? That seems like it will confuse operators.

I suggest that, if this option is set to True, requests to boot in a non-secure mode are rejected.

If we reject the non-secure boot mode requests than operator cannot provision the nodes for plain UEFI as well.  We can allow deploy request with "boot_mode":"uefi" and provision it using UEFI boot mode.

However, we should reject the deploy request in BIOS boot mode when 
"boot_mode":"bios". 
Changing the boot mode to BIOS will impact subsequent deploy in secure_deploy_mode. One cannot change the boot mode to UEFI and enable secure boot with a single reboot.

What do you think?
will you introduce a new error message to indicate that a deploy failed because the deploy ramdisk wasn't signed // couldn't be started in secure-boot-mode?
It is not possible to validate if the deploy ramdisk is signed or not, but would throw the deploy failue exception if the instance requested boot mode is BIOS.

Up to here, nothing is new, right? The 'secure_boot' capability /workflow you describe already exists [1].

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic/drivers/ilo.html#uefi-secure-boot-support

Yes. No change in how request is made.
Only upon receiving request, if the new conf variable is enabled bare metal would boot in UEFI secure boot mode and continue with the deploy process.
Which group will this config be in? [default], [deploy] or [ilo] or ?
It would be under 'ilo'. Will update the spec.

I'm confused here. How is the user going to distinguish what they were getting before when they set the 'secure_boot' capability, vs what will happen with this change? They didn't do anything different from the API part.
The end-user would not know. This feature is more for the cloud operator who wants to use UEFI secure boot all throughout when deploy request if for an UEFI secure boot instance.
are you proposing a generic procedure or ilo-specific one? it sounded pretty generic until you mentioned ilo here
Sure. Done.
if you define a generic interfaces, they might eventually support it. So I suggest moving this option under [agent]
It could have been generic, but no other driver supports uefi secure boot .

specs/approved/secure-baremetal-deploy-i.message: I know this has come up before, but I'm honestly not sure that agent is the best place to put this setting, since the intent is to support the behavior with even the PXE drivers.
I agree. Have proposed it under 'deploy' group. I could not find any other appropriate group. What do you think>
what's the reason to add such option? looks like an overcomplication.
Since this is a deployment option it cannot be part of capabilities. We already have 'secure_boot' as a capability that is used for bringing up the instance in secure boot mode.

Secure boot can be enabled and disabled. 

To enable secure boot-> Node needs to be in UEFI boot mode. 'Turn on secure boot' and reset the server. Server will boot in UEFI secure boot mode
To disable secure boot-> 'turn Off secure boot' and reset the server. Server will boot in UEFI boot mode.

If we turn this feature is not configurable, then the nodes associated with this conductor cannot be used for deploying in BIOS boot mode. They can either be deployed in UEFI or UEFI secure boot mode. This is the reason to make it configurable.

I get it, but that does not explain "why". I'm not fond configuration options to enable/disable features. We did it only twice (IIRC) and for serious reasons. Do we have an option to disable secure_boot, for example?
I'm not sure why we need this.
Same as above.

What is the plan for testing this? We don't have DIB images in the gate at all today. Will iLo 3rd party CI run a job with this enabled?

Please address testing this in the spec work items. Thanks!
Yes. It would be tested with iLO 3rd party CI. Have updated this in 'Testing' section
nit: If ... is set
Done

Hm, why does nova dictate if we use secure boot for the deploy ramdisk? Isn't this related only to ironic?

Or does secure_deploy also mean the user image is booted with secure_boot?
Yes, secure_deploy requires both deploy ramdisk and user image to be signed. Provisioning happens in UEFI secure boot mode and user image boots in secure boot mode.

instance support for UEFI secure boot mode is already implemented, and is determined by two things today, as I understand it.

- Ironic node.properties['capabilities']['secure_boot'] = True
- Nova flavor['extra_specs']['capabilities:secure_boot'] = True

This proposal adds another key to the Nova flavor, namely "secure_deploy". 

Is there a use case for doing either one (secure deploy or secure boot) but not both?

If so, please outline that use case here.

If not, then why not merely add this capability to Ironic, without exposing any changes to Nova?

It is possible to enhance capability secure_boot to support deploy in uefi-secure-boot mode. But this would cause a backward compatibility issue in two ways:-
1. So far, user could have used unsigned deploy image to provision node in secure boot mode. Only instance image was required to be signed.

2. For the node to provision in uefi-secure-boot mode, node always needs to be at least in 'uefi' boot mode. Node cannot be set into secure boot if it is in bios boot mode. 
The change from bios boot mode to uefi-secure-boot mode needs 2 reboots. viz. bios-to-uefi and then uefi to uefi-secure-boot mode. We cannot have 2 node restarts during provisioning.
In current implementation of uefi-secure-boot using 'secure_boot' capability, we disable secure boot during tear_down() when node is powered off. 
When node powers up for the provisioning, it boots into 'uefi' boot mode. When instance image boots up, it can change boot mode to 'bios' or enable uefi-secure-boot as required by flavor during continue_deploy(). 
This gives ability to the drivers to re-provision a node in any boot mode when 'secure_boot' capability is used.

When proposed  'secure_deploy' capability is used, node can never be booted into 'bios' boot mode. This will cause limitation to the users who want to use node for provisioning with bios or uefi or uefi-secure-boot modes.

The proposed secure_deploy capability should be used when user want to use node only for uefi-secure-deploy.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/ingress.message:
If this function is just returning number of platform cores or platform cpus, then rename it to reflect what it actually is.

If this returning the limits and/or required, in theory could return the formatted limits dictionary, since that block of code is repeating, and possibly in other places now that need it.  May want a generic function to create/format limits and required dictionary based on (cpu, memory, etc), default None to omit. 

Would we ever want fractional limits? Can leave as-is, just a question.
it might not flexible for different situations. For example, the keys of dict are different.

How much memory and cpu usage is actually needed for ingress?

This function is returning the platform configured number of logical cpus and the platform configured reserved memory for controller-0.   In theory this means ingress can take 100% of the platform resources on AIO, which makes this pretty much unbounded. For example, we don't want ingres to be able to take 2 or 4 cores worth of cpu power, and we don't want it to be able to consume the full 16GB of memory.

The values chosen should be an over-engineered setting that takes into account the platform limits as maximum, and what is actually required by ingres.

Eg.
ingres_limit_cpus = min(ingres_eng_cpus, platform_limit_cpus)
ingres_limit_mem = min(ingres_eng_mem, platform_limit_mem)

Given we have cpu manager policy None for openstack, we can get away very big values for these. Perhaps more appropriate values would be ingres_eng_cpus = 1, ingres_eng_mem = 1GiB (not I did not look iun detail at the usage stats).

But if you do look at the ingres pod:
/sys/fs/cgroup/memory/k8s-infra/kubepods/besteffort/podddcd502c-b218-11e9-b65b-001b2176fa24/27e9d5dace4758b776ec0709f0aa75b60c7f9eb02ed92b557536cd237eac954c#
memory.max_usage_in_bytes

The original policy does not limit both CPU and Mem usage. LP #1834799 wants to limit the CPU usage on AIO since it only reserves part of CPUs for platform usage. The Mem usage was not reported as an issue. So this patch only limits the CPU usage.

LP #1834799 is set to high since CPU usage does impact system performance. To optimize the Mem usage is another topic which should be addressed by another LP with different priority.
I think "%d" would make more sense.
It always uses xxxm in openstack helm charts. Should we align with original value?
The LP requested that the CPU usage be limited. Why are you also limiting memory?

the original helm chart has both CPU and Mem limit setting. If the resources limit is enabled, both of them will be enabled. But the original Mem limit is small which might lead to OOM. We met such OOM when enabling the resources limit of rabbitmq. So we must change the MEM limit default value here.
